ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Analyze and synthesize philosophical and political texts.

By taking this course, I learned about human motivation, reading both classical texts like Hume and Rousseau, and more contemporary works like an economic analysis of human behavior and empirical psychological texts.

I developed an understanding of the ways in which self-interest and rational choice theory have a robust history in Western political thought, and how this tradition may impact the ways in which we understand the world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength of this course is it's in-depth focus on reading texts with the lens of self-interest and human motivation. It is also strong in its evaluation of the ethics behind motivating people. A weakness would be that toward the end of the semester, it feels like everything new and interesting about the topic has been exhausted.

I thought that the second half of the course was extremely interesting, and would have loved to hear more about recent work on rational choice and self-interest theory. The early works are necessary, but I can't help but wished they had been compressed into a few weeks fewer.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this class to anyone interested in political theory.
I would recommend this course to another student, especially those who are interested in political philosophy, self-interest, and altruism.

I would definitely recommend this course to another EP&E major. I think this course is the ideal EP&E course, as it really does hit on all three facets of the interdisciplinary major. I really enjoyed the class in that regard. It also felt DS-like in that it's a survey seminar course--just, it focuses on one lens with which to examine texts.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone curious about how self-interest is deeply ingrained into society and our everyday lives.
